DOC.detailed_description: Introduction . Post cesarean section pain control challenge task since one ten painful surgery . Multiple strategy propose pain control , include neuraxial analgesia , systemic opioids , non-opioid drug peripheral nerve block , among others . Transversus abdominal plane ( TAP ) block prove provide effective analgesia use part multimodal analgesic regimen abdominal surgery become popular technique post cesarean section analgesia , although recent report local anesthesia toxicity raise concern safety population . Currently information pharmacokinetics levobupivacaine technique pregnant patient guide dose safe way . Our objective generate pharmacokinetic model characterize plasmatic level levobupivacaine co-administered epinephrine effect ECG , TAP block post cesarean section patient . Methods . After institutional ethic committee approval write informed consent , 12 term pregnant patient American Society Anesthesiologists physical status I II , schedule elective cesarean section recruit prospective , single-blind pharmacokinetic study . Patients exclude allergy/sensitivity local anaesthetic , significant renal liver dysfunction . An intravenous ( 18-gauge ) catheter place local anesthesia co hydration . After initiation standard monitoring ( continuous electrocardiogram , noninvasive arterial blood pressure , pulse oximetry ) , patient receive spinal anesthesia L3-L4 L4-L5 interspace hyperbaric bupivacaine 0,75 % 1,4 ml plus 20 ug fentanyl achieve bilateral anesthetic level T4 determine pinprick . After surgery , TAP block perform 20 mL 0.25 % levobupivacaine , epinephrine 1:200.000 ( 5 ug/ml ) side , ultrasound ( US ) guidance . One anesthesiologist experience technique perform TAP block use US Sonosite M-Turbo US machine ( Sonosite Inc , Washington ) L38x 10-5 megahertz ( MHz ) , 38-mm broadband linear array probe . A second anesthesiologist evaluate approve US image administration mixture . Blocks perform 21 gauge ( G ) , 110-mm spinal Quincke needle ( N. Medical Industries Ltd. , Japan ) use in-plane approach .
